node.title: Meadows Agrees to Cooperate in Capitol Attack Investigation
node.alt: The change of stance for Mark Meadows comes as the panel is pursuing a criminal contempt of Congress referral for a second witness who has stonewalled one of its subpoenas.
node.description: Donald J. Trump’s former chief of staff, Mark Meadows, has turned over documents and agreed to be deposed in the House’s inquiry into the Jan. 6 attack.
node.content: ["WASHINGTON \u2014 Mark Meadows, the former White House chief of staff under President Donald J. Trump, has reached an agreement with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol to provide documents and sit for a deposition, the panel said on Tuesday, a stunning reversal for a crucial witness in the inquiry.", "The change of stance for Mr. Meadows, who had previously refused to cooperate with the committee in line with a directive from Mr. Trump, came as the panel prepared to seek criminal contempt of Congress charges against a second witness who has stonewalled its subpoenas. It marked a turnabout after weeks of private wrangling between the former chief of staff and the select committee over whether he would participate in the investigation, and to what degree.", "\u201cMr. Meadows has been engaging with the select committee through his attorney,\u201d Representative Bennie G. Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi and chairman of the panel, said in a statement. \u201cHe has produced records to the committee and will soon appear for an initial deposition.\u201d", "Mr. Thompson indicated that he was withholding judgment about whether Mr. Meadows was willing to cooperate sufficiently, adding, \u201cThe committee will continue to assess his degree of compliance with our subpoena after the deposition.\u201d", "His deposition is expected to be private, as has been the panel\u2019s practice with other witnesses.", "Mr. Meadows\u2019s lawyer, George J. Terwilliger III, also suggested that there were strict limits to his client\u2019s willingness to participate in the inquiry.", "\u201cAs we have from the beginning, we continue to work with the select committee and its staff to see if we can reach an accommodation that does not require Mr. Meadows to waive executive privilege or to forfeit the longstanding position that senior White House aides cannot be compelled to testify before Congress,\u201d Mr. Terwilliger said in a statement. \u201cWe appreciate the select committee\u2019s openness to receiving voluntary responses on non-privileged topics.\u201d", "CNN earlier reported that Mr. Meadows\u2019s had reached a deal with the panel.", "Citing a claim of executing privilege from Mr. Trump, Mr. Meadows\u2019s lawyer, Mr. Terwilliger wrote to the committee on Nov. 10 saying that his client could not \u201cin good conscience\u201d provide testimony out of an \u201cappreciation for our constitutional system and the separation of powers,\u201d asserting that doing so would \u201cundermine the office and all who hold it.\u201d", "That stance was condemned by the leaders of the committee, Mr. Thompson and Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming and the vice chairwoman, who accused Mr. Meadows of defying a lawful subpoena. They said they would consider pursuing contempt charges to enforce it.", "Mr. Thompson and Ms. Cheney called Mr. Trump\u2019s privilege claims \u201cspurious,\u201d and added that many of the matters they wished to discuss with Mr. Meadows \u201care not even conceivably subject to any privilege claim, even if there were one.\u201d", "Among their questions, they said, were whether he was using a private cellphone to communicate on Jan. 6 and the location of his text messages from that day.", "", "The select committee issued a subpoena for Mr. Meadows\u2019s records and testimony in September, citing his involvement in the planning of efforts to subvert the results of the 2020 election. In Mr. Trump\u2019s final weeks in office, Mr. Meadows repeatedly pushed the Justice Department to investigate unfounded conspiracy theories, according to emails provided to Congress, portions of which were reviewed by The New York Times. He was also in communication with organizers of the rally on Jan. 6 that preceded the violence, including Amy Kremer of Women for America First, the committee said.", "The committee on Wednesday is expected to begin contempt of Congress proceedings against Jeffrey Clark, a former Justice Department official involved in Mr. Trump\u2019s effort to upend the election.", "The vote would be the second such confrontation between the committee and an ally of Mr. Trump since Congress began investigating the circumstances surrounding the Capitol riot, which resulted in multiple deaths and dozens of injuries.", "The House voted in October to recommend that another of Mr. Trump\u2019s associates, Stephen K. Bannon, be charged with criminal contempt of Congress for stonewalling the inquiry.", "A federal grand jury subsequently indicted him on two counts that could carry up to two years behind bars in total."]
